episode.title: Lamb's Chapel v. Center Moriches Union Free School District

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: We'll hear argument first this morning in number 91-2024, Lamb's Chapel and John Stig... Steigerwald v. Center Moriches Union Free School District.
Mr. Sekulow.

turn.speaker: jay_alan_sekulow
turn.label: Mr. Jay A. Sekulow
turn.text: Mr. Chief Justice and may it please the Court:
This case is about censorship of Lamb's Chapel's speech, which was entertained for the purpose of having a film series at the school facilities to show and discuss contemporary family issues.
The direct targeting of religious purpose as an exclusion under the access policy of the school district is both content based and viewpoint based, and does not meet Constitutional scrutiny.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Under what?

turn.speaker: jay_alan_sekulow
turn.label: Mr. Jay A. Sekulow
turn.text: Under... well first of all, we would assert that it's purely... this case is based purely on religious perspective, it's viewpoint based.
Most recently, R.A.V., but also under--

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Well, so--

turn.speaker: jay_alan_sekulow
turn.label: Mr. Jay A. Sekulow
turn.text: --Yes, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: --So what... what provision of the Constitution are you relying on?

turn.speaker: jay_alan_sekulow
turn.label: Mr. Jay A. Sekulow
turn.text: First Amendment, as applied to the States through the Fourteenth, freedom of speech.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Which part of it?

turn.speaker: jay_alan_sekulow
turn.label: Mr. Jay A. Sekulow
turn.text: Free speech.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Just free speech.

turn.speaker: jay_alan_sekulow
turn.label: Mr. Jay A. Sekulow
turn.text: Well, this case is based on three issues when it was originally brought fourth in the complaint.
The First Amendment's freedom of speech clause, there was an allegation that there was a violation of the establishment clause, and there was an allegation that there was violation of free exercise.
And, quite frankly, the nature of the discrimination that takes place here in the context of Lamb's Chapel's application being denied violates all three.
From the First Amendment perspective--

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: What did the... what did the court of appeals decide?

turn.speaker: jay_alan_sekulow
turn.label: Mr. Jay A. Sekulow
turn.text: --The court of appeals came to the conclusion that acknowledging that there were a wide diversity of uses, which the respondents have conceded as well, that, in fact, because there were no prior religious uses, the... the school district could then not allow Lamb's Chapel to meet.

They held, in fact, that it was a close question whether there was prior religious uses, but determined, based on review of the Salvation Army being there, the Southern Gospel Harmonizers, that it was no... there was no previous religious purpose in any meaningful way.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Well, as the case comes to us, do we judge it on the basis that the court of appeals was correct in saying that... that this program had a religious purpose?

turn.speaker: jay_alan_sekulow
turn.label: Mr. Jay A. Sekulow
turn.text: The respondents have... petitioners have conceded Your Honor, Justice White, that yes, the... the movie series was dealing with contemporary family issues from a... a religious perspective and are quite up front that it is for a religious purpose.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: All right.

turn.speaker: jay_alan_sekulow
turn.label: Mr. Jay A. Sekulow
turn.text: Our concern here, and I think what is evident here, is that the viewpoint discrimination that has been engaged in by the school district comes from their own admissions.
The respondents have stated that the decision... and I'm quoting from their brief.
"The decision to exclude petitioners was due to the admittedly religious nature of the film and the school district's prohibition against the use of school property for religious purposes. "
They then state that, and again quoting,
"Each of these applications were denied due to the decidedly religious perspective of the film. "

If Lamb's Chapel Church desired to utilize school facilities during noninstructional time in the evening, pursuant to the school's access policy, and if they determined to discuss the same issues, contemporary family issues, with the sole exception being that they do not make religious references or religious perspectives, then Center Moriches could not object to allowing the group to be there.
This isn't a case where we are arguing that a school district must open its facilities to a broad array of uses.

Here the school district, by policy, has stated that they are opening their facilities to community use for social, civic, recreational purposes and other uses pertaining to the welfare of the community.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: What about political speech?

turn.speaker: jay_alan_sekulow
turn.label: Mr. Jay A. Sekulow
turn.text: They actually allow political speech, however--

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: What does the... what does the rule say?

turn.speaker: jay_alan_sekulow
turn.label: Mr. Jay A. Sekulow
turn.text: --The rule says this, that political speech could take place, political meetings could take place.

However if, in fact, the political meetings were partisan, if they were sponsored by a political organization, then there would have to be a vote of the district to determine whether, in fact, that group could meet, which I think presents another Constitutional issue which is not one that we're... we're concerned with today, but I think it points to the problem.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Well, I know, but religious speech is not the only speech that is at least presumptively barred.

turn.speaker: jay_alan_sekulow
turn.label: Mr. Jay A. Sekulow
turn.text: Political speech by a party has to go through an admission process, if you will.

So... but here, and I think what's relevant here is this is not a question of where, Justice White, they've eliminated or construed their statute to remove the subject matter of family issues from the permissible speech.
This is not a question of whether the speech topic was permissible, nor is this really a question of whether the group was entitled to access.
Clearly the admission policy, the use policy of the school district states that it is open to not-for-profit outside groups.
Here the exclusion was based... as they have conceded, based on its content, the nature of the film, its viewpoint, its perspective.
And they've allowed, in other existing uses, several discussions on family issues.
For instance--

turn.speaker: david_h_souter
turn.label: Justice David H. Souter
turn.text: Mr.... Mr. Sekulow--

turn.speaker: jay_alan_sekulow
turn.label: Mr. Jay A. Sekulow
turn.text: --Yes, Justice--

turn.speaker: david_h_souter
turn.label: Justice David H. Souter
turn.text: --You would... on your view, you would also be entitled to win, wouldn't you, if we don't accept your characterization of it as viewpoint based, but held it to be content based.
On your theory, you'd still win, wouldn't you?

turn.speaker: jay_alan_sekulow
turn.label: Mr. Jay A. Sekulow
turn.text: --Yes, we do, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: david_h_souter
turn.label: Justice David H. Souter
turn.text: So that if we said what was excluded was simply discussions of religion or religious proselytization, you would still, on your viewpoint, win.

turn.speaker: jay_alan_sekulow
turn.label: Mr. Jay A. Sekulow
turn.text: Certainly, especially in the context of the policy that the school district has adopted here.
The... the school district has adopted a policy which, as I said, opens its facilities to social, civic, recreational use and other uses pertaining to the welfare of the community.
Our submission is quite clear that we believe the religious perspective, religious discussions, serve civic, social, and welfare of the community needs.
So--

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: But what if the school district had adopted a policy of excluding both religious and political speech on the grounds these tend to cause controversy and arguments and we'd just rather stay away from them?

turn.speaker: jay_alan_sekulow
turn.label: Mr. Jay A. Sekulow
turn.text: --I... I still would say, Mr. Chief Justice, that that would not... could not justify the exclusion.
Because the policy here, in its beginning, opens up facilities uses... that's again for social, civic, recreational purposes.
I think the religious view or religious perspective on social, civic, and welfare of the community needs is relevant, and there's no basis upon which--

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: Well--

turn.speaker: jay_alan_sekulow
turn.label: Mr. Jay A. Sekulow
turn.text: --Unless, of course, a compelling interest could be shown.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: --Could... could... could the State exclude only partisan political speech and say that we just don't want to get into that sort of thing?

turn.speaker: jay_alan_sekulow
turn.label: Mr. Jay A. Sekulow
turn.text: I think that brings up a different question, but here the... the free exercise issue would come up and I think an establishment clause issue comes up in the context of our case.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: How about the... how about the... how about the political question--

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: --You were just asked?

turn.speaker: jay_alan_sekulow
turn.label: Mr. Jay A. Sekulow
turn.text: --I think that political--

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: But didn't answer, yeah.

turn.speaker: jay_alan_sekulow
turn.label: Mr. Jay A. Sekulow
turn.text: --Political speech is appropriate in the designation that the school district has adopted.
Could a school district adopt one that narrowly tailors and says no political speech because of our concerns?
Maybe they could, but that's not what they've done here.
And I... I think that maybe--

turn.speaker: anthony_m_kennedy
turn.label: Justice Anthony M. Kennedy
turn.text: Well, but what's the difference.
It... it seems to me--

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: --You still haven't answered it.

turn.speaker: anthony_m_kennedy
turn.label: Justice Anthony M. Kennedy
turn.text: It seems to me you haven't answered the question.

turn.speaker: jay_alan_sekulow
turn.label: Mr. Jay A. Sekulow
turn.text: --I don't think that you can say--

turn.speaker: anthony_m_kennedy
turn.label: Justice Anthony M. Kennedy
turn.text: You talk about free exercise.
We're talking about... just about speech.
If there is a... a prohibition against political speech, is that valid?
And if not, how is that different from the case we have here?

turn.speaker: jay_alan_sekulow
turn.label: Mr. Jay A. Sekulow
turn.text: --A prohibition--

turn.speaker: anthony_m_kennedy
turn.label: Justice Anthony M. Kennedy
turn.text: That's the question you've been asked.

turn.speaker: jay_alan_sekulow
turn.label: Mr. Jay A. Sekulow
turn.text: --Justice Kennedy, if there was a prohibition on just political speech, I think it suffers the same Constitutional defect.
It has... there has to be some type of compelling interest here to justify the exclusion, especially when the subject matter is a valid topic.
And I... I would also point out here that there were discussions of civic issues, political issues, meet-the-candidates nights.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: Well... well then you're saying that if a school district opens up its forum to any outsiders, it's got to... up... open it up across the board.

turn.speaker: jay_alan_sekulow
turn.label: Mr. Jay A. Sekulow
turn.text: No... no I'm not, Mr. Chief Justice.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: Well it seems to me that's what you're saying.

turn.speaker: jay_alan_sekulow
turn.label: Mr. Jay A. Sekulow
turn.text: No.
What we're saying is this.
The school district here has adopted a policy that states that social, civic, recreational uses and other uses pertaining to the welfare of the community can take place.
They've made the affirmative determination that, in fact, those type of activities can take place.
A school district certainly can... a school district could close its facilities.
They're not... they're not being compelled to open them--

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: But doesn't... doesn't political speech fall under that category, that... that... that--

turn.speaker: jay_alan_sekulow
turn.label: Mr. Jay A. Sekulow
turn.text: --I believe... I believe it does, Justice Scalia.
That's what I was saying too--

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: --Hum.

turn.speaker: jay_alan_sekulow
turn.label: Mr. Jay A. Sekulow
turn.text: --The question here is not whether political speech can take place, because under the policy political speech can take place.
The exclusion is if it's of a... from a partisan organization, and I think that suffers from Constitutional defects as well.

turn.speaker: david_h_souter
turn.label: Justice David H. Souter
turn.text: Also, by the same token would you say that if they... they could not exclude a... a religious service, for example.
If an outside group wanted to... to celebrate a mass or a baptism or something like that, could the... I presume, by a parity of reasoning, that could not be excluded.

turn.speaker: jay_alan_sekulow
turn.label: Mr. Jay A. Sekulow
turn.text: I think under the policy that's been adopted, Justice Souter, that removing a service, religious service, would suffer the same Constitutional problems.
And I would state that what this Court said in Widmar is... is relevant to that.
In Widmar the Bible group meeting of Cornerstone was in... in reality a service.
There were hymns, there was singing, there were discussions on biblical commentary.

That is a church service and I don't think that a school district that decides to open its facilities... as I said, they don't have to open their racilities, they've decided to open their facilities... can then parse the speech so closely to determine when religious speech crosses the line, if you will, to a religious service.

turn.speaker: david_h_souter
turn.label: Justice David H. Souter
turn.text: But are... are you accepting the... the ultimate premise of the other side that they can, in fact, define the extent to which they open it up?

turn.speaker: jay_alan_sekulow
turn.label: Mr. Jay A. Sekulow
turn.text: I think they can in the extent of speaker identification, clearly, and as regard to the subject matter of the discussion.
But to have an exclusion on--

turn.speaker: david_h_souter
turn.label: Justice David H. Souter
turn.text: So the answer is there... quite clearly, they could exclude all political speech and they could exclude all religious speech.

turn.speaker: jay_alan_sekulow
turn.label: Mr. Jay A. Sekulow
turn.text: --Not when the... Justice Souter, not when the policy granting access says social--

turn.speaker: david_h_souter
turn.label: Justice David H. Souter
turn.text: No, no.
But you were... you're just changing the premise of my question.
My... the premise of my question was that their policy granting access says no religious speech, no political speech.
On your view, that would be permissible.

turn.speaker: jay_alan_sekulow
turn.label: Mr. Jay A. Sekulow
turn.text: --Not in the context... well, if it was just a flat... there were no outside groups for other purposes.
I think the... the hypothetical that you're giving depends on... and I don't want to change the hypothetical--

turn.speaker: david_h_souter
turn.label: Justice David H. Souter
turn.text: Yeah, there would be outside groups for other purposes, there just wouldn't be outside groups for political purposes and religious purposes.

turn.speaker: jay_alan_sekulow
turn.label: Mr. Jay A. Sekulow
turn.text: --I... I don't think that would... would be a valid exclusion.

turn.speaker: david_h_souter
turn.label: Justice David H. Souter
turn.text: Well, why not?
I thought your argument was proceeding on the fact that they've opened the doors wide and they cannot then pick and choose within the extent to which they have opened them.
But that apparently isn't your argument and you're now saying they've got to open the doors wide.

turn.speaker: jay_alan_sekulow
turn.label: Mr. Jay A. Sekulow
turn.text: Absolutely not, Justice Souter.

turn.speaker: david_h_souter
turn.label: Justice David H. Souter
turn.text: Then how do we draw the line?

turn.speaker: jay_alan_sekulow
turn.label: Mr. Jay A. Sekulow
turn.text: Let me make... let me make the position... what we're saying is this.
The school district here has elected to open its facilities and they've conceded to a wide diversity of uses.
They have targeted the religious purpose speech for exclusion.
They have conceded that the religious exclusion in our case is based on the perspective of the film series and its religious nature, that's their concessions.

Once you have an... a governmental municipality organization opening up its facilities to social, civic, recreational uses and other uses pertaining to the welfare of the community, they cannot then close it because of a religious perspective.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: Is your... is your theory, Mr. Sekulow, that you cannot pick on religion, that... that... that if religion is just one of many things excluded it's okay.

turn.speaker: jay_alan_sekulow
turn.label: Mr. Jay A. Sekulow
turn.text: No.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: But if it's the only thing excluded or one of only a couple of things excluded, it's not okay.

turn.speaker: jay_alan_sekulow
turn.label: Mr. Jay A. Sekulow
turn.text: My position is... this is my position, that when you open up a school district... when a school district elects to open up its facilities for community use for such uses as social, civic, and welfare of the community needs, you cannot exclude the religious perspective.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: Why?
Because that includes too many needs.

turn.speaker: jay_alan_sekulow
turn.label: Mr. Jay A. Sekulow
turn.text: No, because the religious perspective is relevant to civic concerns.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: Oh--

turn.speaker: jay_alan_sekulow
turn.label: Mr. Jay A. Sekulow
turn.text: And that's... and that's where the viewpoint discrimination is here.
And I think the... the record in our case points that out quite clearly, Justice Kennedy.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: --But they haven't... but they haven't said civic concerns.
They've said civic concerns except religious concerns.

turn.speaker: jay_alan_sekulow
turn.label: Mr. Jay A. Sekulow
turn.text: No, actually--

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: I mean don't--

turn.speaker: jay_alan_sekulow
turn.label: Mr. Jay A. Sekulow
turn.text: --Precisely what they've said is we are allowing outside not-for-profit groups to utilize school facilities due... for access policy... under our access policy for social... meetings for social, civic, recreational purposes--

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: --Yes.

turn.speaker: jay_alan_sekulow
turn.label: Mr. Jay A. Sekulow
turn.text: --And other uses pertaining to the welfare of the community.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: But heaven's not there and they've said except--

turn.speaker: jay_alan_sekulow
turn.label: Mr. Jay A. Sekulow
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: --Religious.

turn.speaker: jay_alan_sekulow
turn.label: Mr. Jay A. Sekulow
turn.text: Right.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: Okay.

turn.speaker: jay_alan_sekulow
turn.label: Mr. Jay A. Sekulow
turn.text: And that's precisely our point.
That is the type of viewpoint discrimination--

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: Yes, why?
Because they've singled out religious--

turn.speaker: jay_alan_sekulow
turn.label: Mr. Jay A. Sekulow
turn.text: --Yes, they have targeted religious speech for exclusion in the nature of the entire--

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: --Right.
Well--

turn.speaker: jay_alan_sekulow
turn.label: Mr. Jay A. Sekulow
turn.text: --Facilities that they've opened up.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: --But... but you would not mind if they singled out religious... religion for exclusion along with a lot of other things.
That if... that is they said we are going to... we are going to have... we are going to allow bowling.

turn.speaker: jay_alan_sekulow
turn.label: Mr. Jay A. Sekulow
turn.text: That's--

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: Nothing else.
We're not going to allow religion, we're not going to allow politics, we're not going to allow other socially good things, you wouldn't have an objection then, would you?

turn.speaker: jay_alan_sekulow
turn.label: Mr. Jay A. Sekulow
turn.text: --No.
But that's the type of subject matter restrictions that a school district in this type of situation certainly... they could say just for bowling, just for tennis.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: But why is that... why is that okay and this one not okay?

turn.speaker: jay_alan_sekulow
turn.label: Mr. Jay A. Sekulow
turn.text: Because here they have opened up the facilities intentionally for social, civic, and welfare of the community needs.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: No, they haven't.
They've said social, civic, and welfare except religious.

turn.speaker: jay_alan_sekulow
turn.label: Mr. Jay A. Sekulow
turn.text: But they've... they have... that's what they cannot do, however.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: We know you say they cannot do it.
Why can they not do it?

turn.speaker: jay_alan_sekulow
turn.label: Mr. Jay A. Sekulow
turn.text: Because this Court has said that viewpoint discrimination, even in a nonpublic forum, is not acceptable.
And I... I don't think that--

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: But you've just said viewpoint discrimination is acceptable if they say we're going to have bowling but we're not going to have--

turn.speaker: jay_alan_sekulow
turn.label: Mr. Jay A. Sekulow
turn.text: --I... I guess the argument could be made if there's a religious perspective on bowling.
But when you open up the topic and the subject matter to social, civic, and welfare of the concerns, and I think the record points to this.
The... there's two things that I think are... are extremely important with regard to the record.

Family Counseling Services, which was an organization that utilized the facilities for counseling, dealt with the... precisely the same issues that the school district would have dealt with... that the church would have dealt with in its film series.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: --You also said that they could not exclude religious services, didn't you?

turn.speaker: jay_alan_sekulow
turn.label: Mr. Jay A. Sekulow
turn.text: I... I think under the policy that they've adopted, they cannot.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: Well, you don't... you don't have to defend some of these rather extreme hypotheticals to win your case.
Your position, I take it, is that since they have had family rearing matters shown and discussed, they can't exclude a family rearing presentation because of a religious perspective in it.

turn.speaker: jay_alan_sekulow
turn.label: Mr. Jay A. Sekulow
turn.text: That's correct.
And that... that is, I think, what... what I was... at bottom, is what this case is about.
This case--

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Well, isn't... isn't... aren't you I would think you would argue that we've already decided this case.
In Widmar.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: --We have argued that this Court's decision in Widmar has decided this case.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Well, you've hardly mentioned it.

turn.speaker: jay_alan_sekulow
turn.label: Mr. Jay A. Sekulow
turn.text: I have not, we've been dealing with the hypotheticals.
[Laughter]
But I will address... I will address the Widmar issue.
But let me say first... answer to the Chief Justice's question and then I will proceed to answer you, Justice White.
This is a case where the identical subject matter, family issues, child abuse, marital conflict, was discussed by Family Counseling Services and a number of other groups.
And the film series, if Lamb's Chapel was allowed to show it, addressed the same issues, albeit from a religious perspective.

And that is what is prohibited by the policy and that is the viewpoint discrimination when the subject matter is acceptable and the speaker's entitled to access, that this Court has said that type of viewpoint discrimination--

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: May I give you one other hypothetical?

turn.speaker: jay_alan_sekulow
turn.label: Mr. Jay A. Sekulow
turn.text: --Certainly, Justice Stevens.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: Supposing there's a group that thinks families would be much healthier and happier and get along better if they all smoked marijuana together, and they came and they want to advocate that under the subject matter of child rearing and family values.
Would they have to give that group access to the facilities?

turn.speaker: jay_alan_sekulow
turn.label: Mr. Jay A. Sekulow
turn.text: I think that, in that case, unless the school district could show a compelling interest to justify the exclusion, they would have the same problem.
And I'm... I'm not so sure they would.
This is not an educational--

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Well, the fact is it would be against the law.

turn.speaker: jay_alan_sekulow
turn.label: Mr. Jay A. Sekulow
turn.text: --Well, that's... that's what I was going to say.
And the compelling interest would be--

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: And the law should be changed in order to accommodate this family value.

turn.speaker: jay_alan_sekulow
turn.label: Mr. Jay A. Sekulow
turn.text: --That's a different hypothetical.
[Laughter]

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: It's the one I had in mind all along.

turn.speaker: jay_alan_sekulow
turn.label: Mr. Jay A. Sekulow
turn.text: The first... the second hypothetical is different.
You're talking about speech that is not advocating--

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: Well say... or just say family value would be promoted by soak... by having the children learn how to smoke cigarettes at an early age.

turn.speaker: jay_alan_sekulow
turn.label: Mr. Jay A. Sekulow
turn.text: --I think perhaps a school district would then have to assert that the health concerns... and now, again, this is another situation not precisely... or really very remote from our case... but where maybe the school district could come up with some compelling interest to justify medical exclusion based on that.

But that's not what happened here, and this is not a case where they're advocating illegal activity, although you would think from the New York Attorney General's perspective that's exactly what's going here.
They... they say religious advocacy is only good to those who already believe... already adherents of the faith.
But Widmar has addressed this issue precisely.

By policy, the school district... the University in Widmar encouraged student groups and stated that they would like... they encouraged student groups to meet and form for social, civic, political, recreational, and educational purposes.
Here, the Center Moriches School District has adopted a policy and--

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: But in Widmar... in Widmar, the group, the religious group that wanted to meet was a student group.

turn.speaker: jay_alan_sekulow
turn.label: Mr. Jay A. Sekulow
turn.text: --I don't think in this case--

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: It was a student group in Widmar.

turn.speaker: jay_alan_sekulow
turn.label: Mr. Jay A. Sekulow
turn.text: --That's correct.
And the school--

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Now I would... I would suppose that... I would suppose that if the school in this case had opened its... had opened its property just for student activities dealing with social and such, but no outside groups whatsoever, you probably wouldn't be here.

turn.speaker: jay_alan_sekulow
turn.label: Mr. Jay A. Sekulow
turn.text: --Correct.
Different case.
And--

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Well yeah, but that... but that happens to be Widmar.

turn.speaker: jay_alan_sekulow
turn.label: Mr. Jay A. Sekulow
turn.text: --But the distinction, and I think the distinction cuts our way here, Justice White, is that in Widmar the university determined to open its school district up for student groups to use it.
Here, the school district determined to open up its school facilities for outside uses.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Exactly.

turn.speaker: jay_alan_sekulow
turn.label: Mr. Jay A. Sekulow
turn.text: So I think the speaker identification restrictions in Widmar and what was adopted here, albeit different, cut our way.
Because what we have is a school district affirmly saying community groups, come in and use our facilities, for precisely the same policy in scope that was in Widmar.
The exclusion is the same as well.
In Widmar the exclusion was that they prohibited school district... university facilities to be used for the purposes of religious worship or teaching.
Here the exclusion states that school district facilities may not, or school premises may not be used for religious purposes, and the justification for the exclusion is the same as well.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: Mr. Sekulow.

turn.speaker: jay_alan_sekulow
turn.label: Mr. Jay A. Sekulow
turn.text: Yes, Justice Scalia.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: Well, on that narrow basis, you know, what you're asking us to do is relatively limited.
You're saying if... if you... if you allow the discussion of a certain topic you cannot permit a religious viewpoint on that topic.

But the next case just around the corner is... is a group that wants to come into this same... the same school district and they say we want to address the... the topic of religion, not... not family, we want to address separately the topic of religion.
And it's not a question of giving a religious viewpoint on some other topic which... which the rules allow, but rather the topic of religion in and of itself which is as a separate topic--

turn.speaker: jay_alan_sekulow
turn.label: Mr. Jay A. Sekulow
turn.text: I believe--

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: --Now.

turn.speaker: jay_alan_sekulow
turn.label: Mr. Jay A. Sekulow
turn.text: --That case is not different, and I'll... here's the reason.

My statement is if the topic... if the preamble to the use application is for social, civic, recreational purposes and other uses pertaining to the welfare of the community, a religious or religion has value, in my client's perspective and others, to civic affairs.
That is where I think the... that's not saying that a school district can--

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: Can it say civic, social, and... and recreational purposes other than politics?
Can it say that?

turn.speaker: jay_alan_sekulow
turn.label: Mr. Jay A. Sekulow
turn.text: --I think politics, political speech, has relevant application to social and civic issues.
I don't think a school district can say that.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: I know it does, but the school says it's just too controversial--

turn.speaker: jay_alan_sekulow
turn.label: Mr. Jay A. Sekulow
turn.text: That would--

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: --And therefore we're going to exclude that from our otherwise all-inclusive program.

turn.speaker: jay_alan_sekulow
turn.label: Mr. Jay A. Sekulow
turn.text: --Not without justifying it by--

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: They can't exclude anything.

turn.speaker: jay_alan_sekulow
turn.label: Mr. Jay A. Sekulow
turn.text: --Yes, Justice Scalia, they can exclude... they could close the forum down.
They could say just bowling.
But they can't open it up to social, civic--

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: Okay, I see.

turn.speaker: jay_alan_sekulow
turn.label: Mr. Jay A. Sekulow
turn.text: --And recreational use and say no to religion or religious perspective.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: Well--

turn.speaker: jay_alan_sekulow
turn.label: Mr. Jay A. Sekulow
turn.text: No to politics, albeit a different case.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: --Well, all candidates for office would be entitled to use the schoolhouse to... to make their speeches then.

turn.speaker: jay_alan_sekulow
turn.label: Mr. Jay A. Sekulow
turn.text: They did, in this case.
The... there was a meeting of the candidates where they each gave their proposal.
And I think that points out what's... what's taken place here.
This isn't a problem where a political group is having trouble getting access; they have had access.
The problem is--

turn.speaker: anthony_m_kennedy
turn.label: Justice Anthony M. Kennedy
turn.text: Mr. Sekulow.

turn.speaker: jay_alan_sekulow
turn.label: Mr. Jay A. Sekulow
turn.text: --Yes, Justice--

turn.speaker: anthony_m_kennedy
turn.label: Justice Anthony M. Kennedy
turn.text: Mr. Sekulow, if I were an attorney for a school board and was listening to your argument, I would go back to my board of education and say if you open your auditorium to two or three different lectures in the community, based on the argument I heard from Mr. Sekulow, you're going to have to allow a Catholic mass to be said in that facility.

Because I've heard him say nothing that would allow the Court to write a decision that gives any kind of reasonable assurance that we can design a category to prevent this use once we have two or three different lecture groups come in from the community at large.

turn.speaker: jay_alan_sekulow
turn.label: Mr. Jay A. Sekulow
turn.text: --I don't think that that would be a difficult policy for the school district to write, Justice Kennedy.

A school district could write a policy, and I don't want to be in the place of writing their policies but can write a policy limiting the subject matter and limiting the speaker identity and still have other groups participate.
But once you open it up to social, civic... this isn't just social, civic, and recreational use.
They also have in their--

turn.speaker: anthony_m_kennedy
turn.label: Justice Anthony M. Kennedy
turn.text: But under your First Amendment submission, which is that there must be absolute content neutrality--

turn.speaker: jay_alan_sekulow
turn.label: Mr. Jay A. Sekulow
turn.text: --Yes.

turn.speaker: anthony_m_kennedy
turn.label: Justice Anthony M. Kennedy
turn.text: --In viewpoint neutrality.

turn.speaker: jay_alan_sekulow
turn.label: Mr. Jay A. Sekulow
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: anthony_m_kennedy
turn.label: Justice Anthony M. Kennedy
turn.text: --I... I contest that you could... could... could accomplish the objective that you've just outlined.

turn.speaker: jay_alan_sekulow
turn.label: Mr. Jay A. Sekulow
turn.text: I think... I'm not... shouldn't be in the position of drafting the regulations, but I would be quite forthright in saying we've thought about that issue and I think a... a policy could be drafted which states that school facilities will be used for recreation.
School facilities will be used for the student groups to discuss student issues.
You don't have to open it up, but when you start opening it up to social, civic, and other uses pertaining to the welfare of the community--

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: It's a question of how broad the other uses are then, isn't it?

turn.speaker: jay_alan_sekulow
turn.label: Mr. Jay A. Sekulow
turn.text: --Absolutely.
And it's not... it's not a--

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: So... so let me come back to the question I asked before but which you... you... you would not answer.
If you... if you exclude religion when you're letting in virtually everything else that seems to be a problem to you.

turn.speaker: jay_alan_sekulow
turn.label: Mr. Jay A. Sekulow
turn.text: --Absolutely.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: But if you're excluding religion when you're excluding a lot of other stuff, that does not seem to be a problem.
Is that the case?

turn.speaker: jay_alan_sekulow
turn.label: Mr. Jay A. Sekulow
turn.text: No.
I don't think--

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: Well then what is the--

turn.speaker: jay_alan_sekulow
turn.label: Mr. Jay A. Sekulow
turn.text: --In the context--

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: --Then I don't understand what the case--

turn.speaker: jay_alan_sekulow
turn.label: Mr. Jay A. Sekulow
turn.text: --Well here's... here's... let me make... put it in at it's bottom.
By policy and practice the school district has determined to open its facilities to these various uses, the social, civic, and welfare of the community.
Having done that--

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: --Except religion.

turn.speaker: jay_alan_sekulow
turn.label: Mr. Jay A. Sekulow
turn.text: --That's right.
But having done that, they cannot exclude it as to religion.
And I think... and the reason is this Court has said--

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: But if they only... if they only let in recreation and theater, then they can exclude religion.

turn.speaker: jay_alan_sekulow
turn.label: Mr. Jay A. Sekulow
turn.text: --I think--

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: Right?
Why is that?

turn.speaker: jay_alan_sekulow
turn.label: Mr. Jay A. Sekulow
turn.text: --Well I don't think if... let me take your theater hypothetical.

If they let in theater groups to perform issues, but then say no to Handel's Messiah... which this school district, by the way, allowed Handel's Messiah but they found that not to be religious in a meaningful way... I don't think they can do that.
But could a school district say we're going to open our facilities to drama groups--

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: No.

turn.speaker: jay_alan_sekulow
turn.label: Mr. Jay A. Sekulow
turn.text: --For the presentation of Shakespeare, yes.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: But they--

turn.speaker: jay_alan_sekulow
turn.label: Mr. Jay A. Sekulow
turn.text: But not have--

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: --But they could say... but they could say no mass.
The could say no mass.

turn.speaker: jay_alan_sekulow
turn.label: Mr. Jay A. Sekulow
turn.text: --Under that policy, yes.
I don't think that's under--

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: Right.
But under this current policy you say they can't even say no mass.

turn.speaker: jay_alan_sekulow
turn.label: Mr. Jay A. Sekulow
turn.text: --I don't--

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: Right?

turn.speaker: jay_alan_sekulow
turn.label: Mr. Jay A. Sekulow
turn.text: --I would have to concede, which I'm not going to, that a mass would be irrelevant to the community good or community welfare or civic, social concerns.
They could draft a policy to prohibit masses.
They could draft a policy to prohibit this film series from showing, but--

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: You say you would have to concede it, but you're not going to.

turn.speaker: jay_alan_sekulow
turn.label: Mr. Jay A. Sekulow
turn.text: --I would not--
[Laughter]

I will... I said I will not concede it because... I'll make that very clear, I believe, and our perspective that we're taking here is that when you open it up to social, civic, and recreational uses and other welfare of the community, that a mass would serve the community.
That doesn't mean everyone has to go to the mass.
This isn't a captive audience.
This isn't a situation where students are there, during the day.
And I think this... what this Court said in Mergens is... is relevant to that.

If a... if high school students were mature enough to understand that a school district does not endorse everything it fails to censor, I think the adults in the community of Center Moriches could do the same.
And I don't think it presents the type of Constitutional dilemma that... that some have made it out to be, that we'll have to allow all religious services.
If allowing the religious service is going to be so divisive to the community that they now can justify the exclusion under this policy, no they can't.

turn.speaker: david_h_souter
turn.label: Justice David H. Souter
turn.text: So you're saying a narrow categorization is possible, and I think you're also saying that if a... if a general categorization, including speech generally is allowed, there cannot be a specific exception to it for subject matter.

turn.speaker: jay_alan_sekulow
turn.label: Mr. Jay A. Sekulow
turn.text: That is correct.

turn.speaker: david_h_souter
turn.label: Justice David H. Souter
turn.text: So it... it simply boils down to a question of the precision with which they specifically identify the permitted uses.

turn.speaker: jay_alan_sekulow
turn.label: Mr. Jay A. Sekulow
turn.text: Absolutely.

This ordinance, although maybe not suffering the same constitutional defect that the Board of Airport Commissioners were, wher it was, you know, no First Amendment activities in here, suffers from that same type of problem.
They have not chosen to narrowly tailor their restrictions.

Instead, what they've done is open it up t social, civic, recreational, and other uses pertaining to the welfare of the community, but say no if it's a religious perspective, no if it's religious content.
Mr. Chief Justice, I'd like to reserve--

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: May I just make sure I understood on of your statements.
You mentioned Shakespeare if they opened up for drama.
Did you say yes or no to the question of whether they could limit it to Shakespeare?

turn.speaker: jay_alan_sekulow
turn.label: Mr. Jay A. Sekulow
turn.text: --I think they could limit it to Shakespeare if they had a... a standard which was specifi saying we're going to have Shakespeare.

But they cannot say we're going to allow drama groups and they exclude Handel's Messiah because we do not want a religious group or discriminate against a religious play if it was opened up to... to drama generally.
And that's what the difference is.
They've not chosen to limit to specifics.
They've been... they've chosen to open it to everything but religion.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: But if they do open it up to... if they open it up to drama generally, they can't be concerned about whether it's just adult drama or teenage drama or any kind of drama, it's just open generally.

turn.speaker: jay_alan_sekulow
turn.label: Mr. Jay A. Sekulow
turn.text: Once they've made that... once they've said we're going to allow our facilities to be used for dramatic productions, you cannot say, now, no to--

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: X-rated movies are okay.

turn.speaker: jay_alan_sekulow
turn.label: Mr. Jay A. Sekulow
turn.text: --That's a different... different question, because that... and here's the difference.
In the drama context, if they open up the drama, open it up to dramatic use, okay, they can then not say no to the religion.
If it's an X-rated movie shown for, for instance, for profit, they've already said that speaker identity won't take place then.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: No, I disagree.

turn.speaker: jay_alan_sekulow
turn.label: Mr. Jay A. Sekulow
turn.text: But if they don't like the movie.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: --Throw in the for profit.

turn.speaker: jay_alan_sekulow
turn.label: Mr. Jay A. Sekulow
turn.text: Okay.
Well, if they're saying an X-rated movie's going to be shown at the school district facilities, this... the analysis I don't think changes Constitutionally.
Again, I think that in... in a real sense, a town... this is the meeting hall, the town hall that was discussed... mentioned in Lemon.

And I think that the interesting issue and the important issue here at bottom is not that school districts have to open its facilities up, not that they can't narrowly tailor them, but once they've opened them up to such a broad array of topics, they cannot exclude religious speech or religious purpose speech, as they have determined.
And here that's exactly what they've done and that type of viewpoint discrimination this Court should not tolerate.
Mr. Chief Justice, I'd like to reserve the rest of my time for rebuttal.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: Very well, Mr. Sekulow.
Mr. Hoefling, we'll hear from you.

turn.speaker: john_w_hoefling
turn.label: Mr. John W. Hoefling
turn.text: Mr. Chief Justice and may it please the Court:

It's the position of the respondent in this case, the Center Moriches School District and the president of the board, that they have denied access to the petitioners in this case based upon a well tailored State statute, the New York State Education Law, section 414, and a series of regulations promulgated under that statute.
We submit that the school district has essentially established a limited public forum, and it not an open public forum, in which certain uses are not permitted.
And we further submit that we have... in the course of using this facility and making it available to certain groups within the community, have been consistent in the uses that we have permitted.

We submit that the petitioner is erroneous... has taken an erroneous position in looking at this particular film series as being part of a larger picture, namely the use of the facility for social, educational, and community welfare activities.

In fact, if you... if you look at the record, both in the district court from the testimony of Pastor Steigerwald and the submission of Pastor Steigerwald in his third application for the use of the premises, in both of those instances he's indicated that he is not prepared to abide by the regulation of the district, and, in fact, he intends to use the facility for educational institution after... for educational... religious education after hours in the school setting.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: Well, what policy of the district was it that Paster Steigerwald said he couldn't or wouldn't abide?

turn.speaker: john_w_hoefling
turn.label: Mr. John W. Hoefling
turn.text: It was... it was number 7, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: Well, you don't have... I mean just state it generally.
You don't have to read it word for word.

turn.speaker: john_w_hoefling
turn.label: Mr. John W. Hoefling
turn.text: Your Honor, the... the policy of the school district with regard to this particular use was that the premises would not be used for religious purposes.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: And that meant any sort of a presentation that had a religious connotation to it.

turn.speaker: john_w_hoefling
turn.label: Mr. John W. Hoefling
turn.text: We submit, Your Honor, that that, as... as the school district has used that policy, means that to the extent somebody... someone is prepared to come forward and use the facilities for the purpose of proselytization or urging somebody to adopt a particular lifestyle which is based upon certain religious precepts, is an... an inappropriate use in our forum.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: Well, would the policy permit someone to come in and urge the adoption of a particular lifestyle that was not based on any religious precepts?

turn.speaker: john_w_hoefling
turn.label: Mr. John W. Hoefling
turn.text: Yes, it would, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: So you would allow lifestyle presentations, lifestyle proselytizing, so to... so to speak, of a secular nature, secularly inspired but not religiously inspired.

turn.speaker: john_w_hoefling
turn.label: Mr. John W. Hoefling
turn.text: Yes, Your Honor, that's correct.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: You think that's consistent with our opinion in Widmar?

turn.speaker: john_w_hoefling
turn.label: Mr. John W. Hoefling
turn.text: Yes, Your Honor, I do.
I... I think that the opinion in Widmar, it's very clear that as to the university students in Widmar, the university is an open forum.
That is not the case in our... in our scenario here.
And, in fact, in allowing an open forum, everybody is entitled to the access that the students--

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: But it seems to me what you're saying is that you have an open forum except for any religious viewpoint.

turn.speaker: john_w_hoefling
turn.label: Mr. John W. Hoefling
turn.text: --No, Your Honor, I respectfully submit that what we've done in this case is establish certain specific uses to which the facility may be put and certain uses to which the facility is... is not allowed to be put.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Yes--

turn.speaker: john_w_hoefling
turn.label: Mr. John W. Hoefling
turn.text: Including... I'm sorry.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: --But it... it is... it isn't... I mean I gather from what you say that a speaker could come in and urge the adaptation of a particular lifestyle so long as he was urging it on a secular basis, but that he... so that that subject matter is permissible.
But a speaker who urges the adoption of a lifestyle based on a religious theme or a religious passage could not do it.

turn.speaker: john_w_hoefling
turn.label: Mr. John W. Hoefling
turn.text: That's correct, Your Honor.

And... and... and the focus of... of the district in looking at religion in this particular regard is that... and it's not just the religious exclusions that we've... that we've fashioned in our regulations and tracked in the State statute, but there are prohibitions in terms of commercial use of the premises and prohibitions with regard to political uses of the premises.

In doing that, the school district is attempting to avoid certain controversial areas which, in terms of religion, if you open the forum to a particular religious use, may well bring you into conflict with establishment problems and may result in entanglement problems which the school district would rather avoid.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: Entanglement.

turn.speaker: john_w_hoefling
turn.label: Mr. John W. Hoefling
turn.text: And in order to avoid that--

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: Entanglement problems?

turn.speaker: john_w_hoefling
turn.label: Mr. John W. Hoefling
turn.text: --Yes, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: Why... why is that?

turn.speaker: john_w_hoefling
turn.label: Mr. John W. Hoefling
turn.text: I submit, Your Honor--

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: That the... the janitor who's going to be in the building.
I don't understand who gets entangled.

turn.speaker: john_w_hoefling
turn.label: Mr. John W. Hoefling
turn.text: --No, Your Honor.
I submit that... I submit that what happens is... one of two things happens.
Either we wind up allowing masses and baptisms and communion and other religious services to occur on the premises.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: Some school districts do that.

turn.speaker: john_w_hoefling
turn.label: Mr. John W. Hoefling
turn.text: I understand that.
And that's certainly--

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: They do it in Virginia.

turn.speaker: john_w_hoefling
turn.label: Mr. John W. Hoefling
turn.text: --That's certainly their right to do that, Your Honor.
But there is no--

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: Well, not according to you.
There's establishment problems.

turn.speaker: john_w_hoefling
turn.label: Mr. John W. Hoefling
turn.text: --No, there's no Constitutional requirement that that be allowed.

turn.speaker: sandra_day_oconnor
turn.label: Justice Sandra Day O'Connor
turn.text: Mr. Hoefling--

turn.speaker: john_w_hoefling
turn.label: Mr. John W. Hoefling
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: --Well, I'm... I'm not talking about a Constitutional requirement.
I'm talking... you were talking about a Constitutional prohibition.

turn.speaker: john_w_hoefling
turn.label: Mr. John W. Hoefling
turn.text: Uh-hum.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: You said there's an establishment problem in doing that.

turn.speaker: john_w_hoefling
turn.label: Mr. John W. Hoefling
turn.text: Yes, Your Honor.
I... I submit that in--

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: So then these Virginia districts that do it, and for all I know... I live in Virginia so I know that it's there, it may well be in other States, you say that... that's a problem.

turn.speaker: john_w_hoefling
turn.label: Mr. John W. Hoefling
turn.text: --Yes, I do, Your Honor.
I submit that--

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: Why is that?

turn.speaker: john_w_hoefling
turn.label: Mr. John W. Hoefling
turn.text: --I submit that... I submit that the first... the first prong of the three-pronged test is that it must have a secular purpose.
And, in fact, it has a religious purpose.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: Uh-hum.

turn.speaker: john_w_hoefling
turn.label: Mr. John W. Hoefling
turn.text: And not a secular purpose.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: Well, let's assume a school district that leases its... its... its facilities for any purpose at all.

turn.speaker: john_w_hoefling
turn.label: Mr. John W. Hoefling
turn.text: Uh-hum.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: You know, commercial, political, anything at all.
They... they must, however, not allow a church group that wants to lease it of a Sunday to conduct a service there.

turn.speaker: john_w_hoefling
turn.label: Mr. John W. Hoefling
turn.text: Yes, Your Honor.
I think that runs into--

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: The Constitution requires that.

turn.speaker: john_w_hoefling
turn.label: Mr. John W. Hoefling
turn.text: --Yes, sir.

And I think it also runs into a problem in terms of the primary effect tends to... to advance religion as a proposition, and that that is also the second prong of the establishment clause test that we run into difficultly with.

I think that in recognition of those problems, the school district has stepped back and attempted to distance itself from religious organizations and kept them out of this otherwise limited forum, as it properly may do under the Constitution.

turn.speaker: sandra_day_oconnor
turn.label: Justice Sandra Day O'Connor
turn.text: Mr. Hoefling.

turn.speaker: john_w_hoefling
turn.label: Mr. John W. Hoefling
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: sandra_day_oconnor
turn.label: Justice Sandra Day O'Connor
turn.text: If... if the university in the Widmar case had adopted the same policy as your school district, do you think the result in the case would have been different?

turn.speaker: john_w_hoefling
turn.label: Mr. John W. Hoefling
turn.text: Well, Your Honor, I submit that in Widmar, as this Court has held, that was an open public forum as to those students because--

turn.speaker: sandra_day_oconnor
turn.label: Justice Sandra Day O'Connor
turn.text: Excuse me.
The question I asked you, though, was whether if the university there had adopted the same policy you've adopted, whether the result in the case would have been the same?

turn.speaker: john_w_hoefling
turn.label: Mr. John W. Hoefling
turn.text: --I think the result in Widmar probably should be the same, because the framework of forum analysis in that case, even with this policy in place in the university, would be a different analysis than the analysis here.
In Widmar--

turn.speaker: sandra_day_oconnor
turn.label: Justice Sandra Day O'Connor
turn.text: Why... why is that, because it's a university and this is not?

turn.speaker: john_w_hoefling
turn.label: Mr. John W. Hoefling
turn.text: --Yes, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: sandra_day_oconnor
turn.label: Justice Sandra Day O'Connor
turn.text: Is that the distinguishing mark, then?

turn.speaker: john_w_hoefling
turn.label: Mr. John W. Hoefling
turn.text: That is... that is the significant difference in the two cases.
As to the students at the university, the university is, in fact, an open forum for ideas and discussion and learning in all types, in all levels.
In our particular case, as to the students who attend the school during the daytime--

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: What if the university in Widmar had--

turn.speaker: john_w_hoefling
turn.label: Mr. John W. Hoefling
turn.text: --I'm sorry, Your Honor?

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: --What if the university in Widmar had adopted exactly the same rule?
It didn't limit access to the university grounds to students or student activities, it said the university facilities are open to all groups for social, welfare organizations, et cetera.
It had exactly the... had exactly your rule but just excluded the political speech and religious speech.

turn.speaker: john_w_hoefling
turn.label: Mr. John W. Hoefling
turn.text: In terms of student groups?

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Wouldn't there... wouldn't Widmar have come out differently?

turn.speaker: john_w_hoefling
turn.label: Mr. John W. Hoefling
turn.text: In terms of student groups, Your Honor?

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: No, no.

turn.speaker: john_w_hoefling
turn.label: Mr. John W. Hoefling
turn.text: Or the community?

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: No, no, no, no.
The same church... the same church wanted to come in and do what... what the church in this case wanted to do.

turn.speaker: john_w_hoefling
turn.label: Mr. John W. Hoefling
turn.text: I understand, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: As the community nonstudent group and there had been hundreds of other nonstudent groups allowed on the university campus, would Widmar have come out differently?

turn.speaker: john_w_hoefling
turn.label: Mr. John W. Hoefling
turn.text: Your Honor, we submit that if it was an off campus nonstudent group who sought access in Widmar, the forum is a different forum than the university forum for students and the result there should have been the same result that we got in the district court and the Second Circuit here.

turn.speaker: david_h_souter
turn.label: Justice David H. Souter
turn.text: You... you seem to be making--

turn.speaker: john_w_hoefling
turn.label: Mr. John W. Hoefling
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: david_h_souter
turn.label: Justice David H. Souter
turn.text: --Two... coming up with two categories that you think are important.
One is a category of university forums, is that correct, that makes a different and that's your... basically, your answer to Justice White's question, I guess?

turn.speaker: john_w_hoefling
turn.label: Mr. John W. Hoefling
turn.text: Well, Your Honor, I... I think that the university itself is an example of an open public forum.

turn.speaker: david_h_souter
turn.label: Justice David H. Souter
turn.text: So it's a... it's necessarily a subset of... of... of what, a designated public forum?

turn.speaker: john_w_hoefling
turn.label: Mr. John W. Hoefling
turn.text: It... the university, in and of itself as to the students, is an open public forum under Widmar.

turn.speaker: david_h_souter
turn.label: Justice David H. Souter
turn.text: Well, it's... is it a... maybe I'm just getting mixed up in definitions, but are you saying it's a designated public forum which is necessarily open?
Once you open a university, you have... so far as the students are concerned, you necessarily have a public forum for the students?

turn.speaker: john_w_hoefling
turn.label: Mr. John W. Hoefling
turn.text: Your Honor, we submit that in terms of a university setting such as the university in Widmar, it was indeed an open public forum.
It has traditionally been--

turn.speaker: david_h_souter
turn.label: Justice David H. Souter
turn.text: I know that's what you're saying, but my question is is that a necessary conclusion that follows from your view of what a university is for First Amendment purposes?

turn.speaker: john_w_hoefling
turn.label: Mr. John W. Hoefling
turn.text: --Yes, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: david_h_souter
turn.label: Justice David H. Souter
turn.text: Okay.
Now, do you... are you also suggesting that in order to win, we recognize... we must recognize in this case a... a fourth forum category, that is the... the limited designated public forum?

turn.speaker: john_w_hoefling
turn.label: Mr. John W. Hoefling
turn.text: Your Honor, I think that the language that comes out in our brief is... is a function of, as much of anything, the language that this Court has used and the language in the Second Circuit.
And we've tried to accommodate those two terms together.

I'm not sure that it's necessary to determine that there is specifically a fourth category of... of speech regulation, but that in our particular case it certainly... this forum, as to outside groups, takes on the appearance of a limited public forum or a designated public forum that has not been opened up to the petitioners.

turn.speaker: david_h_souter
turn.label: Justice David H. Souter
turn.text: Okay.
So you're... you're saying a... a designated public forum can have limitations, but it cannot in a university setting with respect to university students, considered in isolation.

turn.speaker: john_w_hoefling
turn.label: Mr. John W. Hoefling
turn.text: As... as to those students, it is an open public forum, Your Honor.
Your Honor, I think that this Court has certainly hinted at that besides the case of Widmar.

There... in Perry, the language of this Court is the right of access extends only to other entities of a similar character, and there is nothing wrong with having some distinction in access on the basis of subject matter and speaker identification.
And--

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: But you exclude... could you exclude communists from conducting any... any family movies?
You could say except those that... that have a communist or socialist viewpoint.

turn.speaker: john_w_hoefling
turn.label: Mr. John W. Hoefling
turn.text: --I don't think--

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: Limited public forum, no communist or socialist viewpoints, is that okay?

turn.speaker: john_w_hoefling
turn.label: Mr. John W. Hoefling
turn.text: --I think that may well run into a different set of problems than the problem we're discussing here today.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: Why... why different?

turn.speaker: john_w_hoefling
turn.label: Mr. John W. Hoefling
turn.text: Because I don't think you have the same establishment clause problems and entanglement problems that you confronted in a--

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: I see--

turn.speaker: john_w_hoefling
turn.label: Mr. John W. Hoefling
turn.text: --In a religious setting.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: --Oh, I see.
You... you defend... that's the defense of your statute, then, that the establishment clause makes you do it.

turn.speaker: john_w_hoefling
turn.label: Mr. John W. Hoefling
turn.text: No, Your Honor.
We submit that it's a limited public forum--

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: Well, then... then don't make that argument then.
Wherein does the example that I gave you differ?

If you are not relying on the establishment clause to say that you cannot do this, then why is it different to exclude a religious viewpoint than to exclude a socialist or communist viewpoint in... in these movies?
Why can't I have a limited public forum, movies on anything you like but no socialists or communists?

turn.speaker: john_w_hoefling
turn.label: Mr. John W. Hoefling
turn.text: --I submit that, again, in terms of areas involving political speech and religious speech--

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: Uh-hum.

turn.speaker: john_w_hoefling
turn.label: Mr. John W. Hoefling
turn.text: --The school district has elected in this particular locality, and in the State of New York, to exclude those types of speakers.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: I know that.

turn.speaker: john_w_hoefling
turn.label: Mr. John W. Hoefling
turn.text: And I submit that--

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: Justice Scalia gave you a hypothetical question.

turn.speaker: john_w_hoefling
turn.label: Mr. John W. Hoefling
turn.text: --Yes.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: You ought to try to answer it.

turn.speaker: john_w_hoefling
turn.label: Mr. John W. Hoefling
turn.text: Yes, Your Honor.
I... I submit that the school district, if it were to characterize those types of speech as political speech, could, in fact, exclude those speakers.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: Is that right?
Just... just that type of political speech.

turn.speaker: john_w_hoefling
turn.label: Mr. John W. Hoefling
turn.text: Yes, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: That's very interesting.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: But do I understand your statement you made earlier that supposing you had a communist group that wanted to address the subject of family values and they thought there was a value in not having children waste their time going to Sunday school or church and therefore they had a point of view that was definitely antireligious, they would be permitted, under your policy, to discuss family values in that context?

turn.speaker: john_w_hoefling
turn.label: Mr. John W. Hoefling
turn.text: Yes.
Yes, Your Honor, that's correct.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: And now why is that not... the contrast between that and what you have here, why is that not viewpoint discrimination?

turn.speaker: john_w_hoefling
turn.label: Mr. John W. Hoefling
turn.text: Your Honor, we... we submit that the... the statute, the scheme that's been established by the statute and the regulations closes the forum to certain particular groups.
One of those groups are people who use the forum to proselytize a particular religious point of view.
That is not something we'd be confronted with by the example you cite.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: But in my... my communist example, why couldn't one make the argument that they are trying to proselytize a nonreligious point of view.
And you're, in effect, discriminating against religions as opposed to those who are totally against religion.

turn.speaker: john_w_hoefling
turn.label: Mr. John W. Hoefling
turn.text: Well, Your Honor, I think, again, that comes down to the focus of how... how narrow it is you look at the speech that's being engaged in.

We've looked at this in terms of religious speech and we haven't compared it to nonreligious speech or irreligious speech or antireligious speech, and we submit that in terms of religious speakers we have been consistent in our policy and that that is permitted within a limited public forum.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: It is lawful because it is.
It is--

turn.speaker: john_w_hoefling
turn.label: Mr. John W. Hoefling
turn.text: It is--

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: --Therefore it is lawful.

turn.speaker: john_w_hoefling
turn.label: Mr. John W. Hoefling
turn.text: --Well, Your Honor, it--

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: No.

turn.speaker: john_w_hoefling
turn.label: Mr. John W. Hoefling
turn.text: --It is lawful to the extent that it has been a longstanding policy and it exhibits the intention of this district and the State of New York not to open up their school districts, across the board, to any and all comers.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: Your... your... your... do I understand your entanglement argument correctly that what you're saying is if we let this particular religious point of view be expressed, well the next step will be the mass and the ceremony.
You're going to have to draw a line somewhere which will involve entanglement in religious decision making, in effect.
Is that what you're arguing?
I don't have the--

turn.speaker: john_w_hoefling
turn.label: Mr. John W. Hoefling
turn.text: Well, I submit that someplace even inbetween there, Your Honor, we... we come up with the question as to what is the next film series--

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: --Right.

turn.speaker: john_w_hoefling
turn.label: Mr. John W. Hoefling
turn.text: --That Lamb's Chapel wants to show and who is it that is going to be speaking at that film series and how much are we to censor or look at or wonder about whether this is permissible or not permissible religious speech--

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Well, it seems--

turn.speaker: john_w_hoefling
turn.label: Mr. John W. Hoefling
turn.text: --On behalf of--

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: --To me your entanglement argument is... doesn't carry much with me because you... because in order to exclude under your no religion rule, you've got to decide whether this... whether this is going to be religion.

turn.speaker: john_w_hoefling
turn.label: Mr. John W. Hoefling
turn.text: --Your Honor, we submit that they have already decided that when they've told us in their application that, in fact, it's going to be religious in nature.
And that's enough for us.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Well that may be so in this case, but you... you're... you're bound to have to decide whether... some group that is going to come in with some program, whether in fact it's a religious program.

turn.speaker: john_w_hoefling
turn.label: Mr. John W. Hoefling
turn.text: We submit that--

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: And... and... and that is the... so you're never going to avoid your entanglement problem.

turn.speaker: john_w_hoefling
turn.label: Mr. John W. Hoefling
turn.text: --Your Honor, we submit that there are often situations in which questions must be asked of a religious group, at least on the surface, to see if they qualify for certain tax benefits or certain other entitlements, but that doesn't necessarily involve entanglement.

But when we get to the point where we are prescreening what they're going to show to see whether or not it's too religious or too close to a mass or a service, too close to proselytizing, that becomes a very difficult issue and really does create entanglement problems for the district.

turn.speaker: anthony_m_kennedy
turn.label: Justice Anthony M. Kennedy
turn.text: Is there a difference between speech with a religious viewpoint and a religious exercise?

turn.speaker: john_w_hoefling
turn.label: Mr. John W. Hoefling
turn.text: Again, I suspect that depends on the nature of the speech, Your Honor, and it's an issue that the school district would rather not get involved in screening.

turn.speaker: anthony_m_kennedy
turn.label: Justice Anthony M. Kennedy
turn.text: Well, the Constitution itself talks about free exercise, so might not that be a workable category?

turn.speaker: john_w_hoefling
turn.label: Mr. John W. Hoefling
turn.text: I have not problem with free exercise in... in a public forum, Your Honor.

But in a limited public forum such as we advocate and the Second Circuit has... the district court and the Second Circuit has found we have here, we see no need to open the forum up to the religious speaker.

turn.speaker: anthony_m_kennedy
turn.label: Justice Anthony M. Kennedy
turn.text: The problem is... is that if you define religion... a limited forum in terms of content, it can be self-defeating because the whole idea of limited... of... of a public forum of some kind is to allow for the expression of speech, so you have to be very careful that you're not just engaging in a circular definition.

turn.speaker: john_w_hoefling
turn.label: Mr. John W. Hoefling
turn.text: I understand that, Judge, but I... Your Honor, Justice Kennedy, I think that if you look at the picture that this Court has drawn, the framework that this Court has put together through the years from Greer and Widmar and Perry and the cases that outline forum analysis, I think it is a useful framework for the school district and for other local government officials to govern what they can and cannot do without running into Constitutional problems in the free speech area.

turn.speaker: sandra_day_oconnor
turn.label: Justice Sandra Day O'Connor
turn.text: Under some of our cases talking about public forum, I think you find an indication that the Court has said that reasonable and neutral limitations can be imposed.
Do you assert that the limitation here on religious content is reasonable and neutral?

turn.speaker: john_w_hoefling
turn.label: Mr. John W. Hoefling
turn.text: Yes, Your Honor, we do.
It's neutral in that--

turn.speaker: sandra_day_oconnor
turn.label: Justice Sandra Day O'Connor
turn.text: That's a little hard to propose.
I'd like you to explain that.

turn.speaker: john_w_hoefling
turn.label: Mr. John W. Hoefling
turn.text: --Yes, Your Honor.
We submit that it's neutral because, in fact, nobody with a religious perspective is permitted to use the facility in terms of proselytizing their faith.

turn.speaker: sandra_day_oconnor
turn.label: Justice Sandra Day O'Connor
turn.text: But people with an antireligious viewpoint are, and so you think that's neutral.

turn.speaker: john_w_hoefling
turn.label: Mr. John W. Hoefling
turn.text: I'm... I'm not certain that that's a fair characterization, but if... if we were to look at that as a hypothetical, I'm not sure--

turn.speaker: sandra_day_oconnor
turn.label: Justice Sandra Day O'Connor
turn.text: You did with Justice Stevens a few minutes ago and I understood you to confirm that.

turn.speaker: john_w_hoefling
turn.label: Mr. John W. Hoefling
turn.text: --Yes, I have no problem with that as a hypothetical.

turn.speaker: sandra_day_oconnor
turn.label: Justice Sandra Day O'Connor
turn.text: So you say that's neutral.

turn.speaker: john_w_hoefling
turn.label: Mr. John W. Hoefling
turn.text: Yes, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: Well, that's like saying that a ban on left wingers is neutral because it includes both communists and socialists.
[Laughter]

turn.speaker: john_w_hoefling
turn.label: Mr. John W. Hoefling
turn.text: Well, in terms of the area of religious freedom in a limited public forum, the school district is concerned with not only the free speech aspects of allowing religious speakers to come in, but they're concerned about establishment problems and they're concerned about entanglement problems.
That is those other categories are not problems that we are confronted with with regard to nonreligious speakers, and on that basis I see a distinction that is worth... worth making.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: Mr. Hoefling--

turn.speaker: john_w_hoefling
